Five Shows to Watch This Week

From the stylish to the tense, from the good-good to the good-bad, there’s something for everyone.

14 Great Disney and Pixar Movies on Netflix

Until Disney launches its own streaming service near the end of 2019, a selection of animated and live-action films will continue to have a home on Netflix. With Pixar’s “Coco” in theaters, it’s a good time to revisit the best Disney and Pixar films the streaming service has to offer.
Read Our Recommendations
Finding Dory
Watch if you’re looking for a sweet, engaging family comedy with beloved characters.
Fantasia
In some respects, it’s remarkable that Walt Disney would produce a classical reverie like “Fantasia” with only two animated features under his belt (“Snow White and the Seven Dwarves” and “Pinocchio”), but then again, audiences didn’t have any hardened notions over what an animated film could be, so Disney could experiment a little.
Pocahontas
There was never going to be a way for Disney to tell the story of John Smith and Pocahontas without softening or outright fudging the historical details, so the sins of “Pocahontas” are baked in.
Hercules
Having revived the Disney brand with “The Little Mermaid” and “Aladdin,” the team of John Musker and Ron Clements turned an eye toward Greek mythology and opted to revive the familiar stories with an irreverent spirit and slangy dialogue.
Mulan
The balancing act between cultural fidelity and Disneyfied whimsy complicates this trip through ancient China as much as it did “Pocahontas,” especially whenever Eddie Murphy pipes up as an Aladdin-like magical dragon named Mushu for comic relief.
Meet the Robinsons
After a whiz kid’s invention is stolen, a time-traveling boy named Wilbur Robinson brings him to the future to find the thief.
Walt Disney Animation Short Films Collection
Although a couple of shorts in this anthology are extensions of previous Disney hits like “Frozen” and “Tangled,” the best examples first appeared before various features in their theatrical runs, including a couple of Oscar winners.
Zootopia
Watch if you’re looking for a colorful and high-spirited family comedy.
The Jungle Book
One of the pitfalls of Disney’s current push to make live-action hits out of its animated catalog is its conservative instinct to follow the animated versions beat-by-beat.
The BFG
Adapted from the children’s book by Roald Dahl, “The BFG” didn’t get the respect that other Steven Spielberg fantasies do, but it deserves a second look.
Pete’s Dragon
Watch for a beautiful and disarmingly sincere ode to nature, family and community.
Moana
Watch for a cheery, delightful family film, filled with memorable songs.
Queen of Katwe
Watch for a feel-good, inspiring family movie based on a true story.
Holes
Watch for a lovably eccentric family film.

Clockwise from lower left: “Get Out,” “John Wick: Chapter 2” and “The Big Sick.”Universal Pictures; Lionsgate; Amazon Studios — Lionsgate

Where to Stream Some of the Best Movies of 2017

The first nine months of the year had their share of great films. Here’s a regularly updated list of where you can stream them.

Stream These 10 Great Films Starring Frances McDormand

Frances McDormand’s leading turn in “Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri” is being praised as one of the finest of her career. But that’s no small claim, considering the variety and power of her filmography thus far.
Read Our Recommendations
Blood Simple
Frances McDormand was a struggling New York stage actress when she landed her first film role in this low-budget thriller, which was also the debut film from the filmmaking brothers Joel and Ethan Coen.
Raising Arizona
Watch if you want to see one of the Coen brothers’ fastest, funniest films.
Mississippi Burning
Frances McDormand’s next film appearance after “Raising Arizona” couldn’t have been more of a departure from what it followed.
Fargo
Watch if you want to see a funny, gripping, offbeat crime story.
Almost Famous
Watch for a personal and evocative coming-of-age story about the pleasures and perils of rock fandom.
Laurel Canyon
Watch for a well-acted adult drama with a libertine SoCal groove.
North Country
Frances McDormand earned her fourth Academy Award nomination for her supporting role in this 2005 drama, based on the true story of the Minnesota class action lawsuit that changed laws regarding sexual harassment in the workplace.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
In recent years, Frances McDormand has had more opportunities to move away from her Serious Actor persona, and have a bit of fun onscreen.
Burn After Reading
After playing so many women of substance, Frances McDormand has what seems to be a great time playing the vapid, shallow gym employee Linda Litzke, who gets in way over her head with a complicated plot involving espionage, adultery, murder, stolen computer discs and (inevitably) the Russians.
Olive Kitteridge
Watch for a brilliantly acted, sprawling tale of small-town disappointment, frustration and repression.

Clockwise from top left: “And Then There Were None,” “Poirot,” “The Witness for the Prosecution” and “Murder on the Orient Express.”Mammoth Screen; Acorn TV; Paramount Pictures

Great Modern Foreign-Language Thrillers

Have you run out of suspenseful English-language movies? This world tour goes from Korea to France to Hong Kong to Mexico.
Read Our Recommendations
Oldboy
Watch for an impeccably crafted and ornately constructed thriller that keeps topping itself.
Caché
Watch for a masterfully orchestrated suspense drama.
A Hijacking
Watch for a foreign “Captain Phillips” with less star power but more tension.
Infernal Affairs
Watch for the sleek, high-energy inspiration for “The Departed.”
Run Lola Run
Tom Tykwer’s international sensation plays like “Speed” for the art-house set, living up to a title that promises a race against the clock and delivers it in the form of a frantic, red-haired woman on the go.
A Prophet
Watch for a pulpy gut-punch of a French prison thriller.
Black Book
After conquering Hollywood with lurid entertainments like “RoboCop,” “Basic Instinct” and “Starship Troopers,” Paul Verhoeven returned to his native Holland for a personal story of resistance and retribution set during World War II.
Revanche
Watch for a slow-burning, character-driven Austrian thriller with gnawing tension and surprising depth.
Lorna’s Silence
The reliably brilliant Dardenne brothers, Jean-Pierre and Luc, are known for social dramas like “Rosetta” and “L’Enfant,” but their interest in characters living on the margins has always given their work the tension of thrillers.
Miss Bala
Watch for a breathless thriller about ordinary people caught in drug-war crossfire.

12 Shows We’ll Be Talking About in November

This month will feature an especially impressive lineup of new shows, with an abundance of big and promising names attached.

10 Underseen Indies From the Past Year on Netflix

Netflix has become a reliable destination for many fine independent films that spent little time in theaters, including a few Netflix productions released directly to the service. Here are ten from 2016 to the present that are worth discovering.
Read Our Recommendations
Tallulah
In this Netflix original and debut feature from the writer-director Sian Heder, a drifter (Ellen Page) kidnaps a neglected child and passes it off as her daughter to her absent boyfriend’s mother (Allison Janney).
Christine
On July 15, 1974, Christine Chubbuck, a broadcast journalist for Channel 40 in Sarasota, Fla.,
Green Is Gold
After his father is sent to prison, a 13-year-old boy moves to the hills of Northern California to live with his older brother, who runs a thriving illegal marijuana plot.
Blue Jay
Mark Duplass is expert at creating semi-improvisational delights, but “Blue Jay” stands out as a bittersweet, perfectly proportioned movie about the road not taken.
Little Sister
The gifted young director Zach Clark follows up “White Reindeer” with another generous, femme-centered character study, this time about the awkward and painful reunion of a dysfunctional family.
Little Men
Watch for an insightful, true portrait of male adolescent friendship.
The Eyes of My Mother
The slicing of an eyeball in Luis Buñuel’s classic surrealist short, “Un Chien Andalou,” is one of cinema’s most famously shocking images.
The Stanford Prison Experiment
In 1971, the Stanford professor Philip Zimbardo recruited 15 male students to take part in a 14-day study on prison abuse, dividing the participants into “guards” and “inmates” and seeing how they responded to their assigned roles.
I Don’t Feel at Home in This World Anymore
Watch for a wildly unpredictable dark comedy.
Tramps
Adam Leon’s debut feature, “Gimme the Loot,” about two graffiti artists on a mission to tag the Mets Home Run Apple, has many virtues, chief among them how vividly it invokes the particular vibe of a Bronx neighborhood.

Stream These 11 Underappreciated TV Shows on Hulu

More than just “The Handmaid’s Tale,” the streaming service has loads of old and new series that may have slipped your attention.

Six Great Movies Under 90 Minutes on Amazon Prime

With all the demands and stresses of modern life, carving out a two-hour chunk of the day isn’t always possible. Amazon Prime has a handful of excellent films of all kinds, from terrifying to adorable, that run at under an hour and a half.
Read Our Recommendations
The Fits (72 minutes)
Watch for an experimental, dreamy indie drama about teen girls.
Krisha (81 minutes)
Watch for the ultimate in holiday counterprogramming, a nerve-shredding portrait of a Thanksgiving in crisis.
Shaun the Sheep (85 minutes)
Watch if you’re looking for a simple yet smart animated movie.
What We Do in the Shadows (85 minutes)
Watch for a comedy that finds what might be the last original slant on the vampire flick.
The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (83 minutes)
In 1974, with a budget of little more than couch change, Tobe Hooper all but wrote the playbook for the four decades of horror cinema that followed.
Boy (87 minutes)
Before the actor, writer and director Taika Waititi got sucked into the Marvel universe (he is directing “Thor: Ragnarok,” scheduled for release this fall) he made clever, idiosyncratic movies set in his native New Zealand.

Here’s How to Make the Most of Your Hulu Subscription

The streaming service is more than just a Netflix competitor. Here’s a look at what it has to offer, including highlights from its current library.

Nine Horror Movies to Watch on Amazon Prime Tonight

Whether you’re looking for gore, ghosts or demonic possession, here are some of the best scary movies on Amazon Prime right now.
Read Our Recommendations
The Witch
Watch if you like slow, atmospheric horror.
The Blackcoat’s Daughter
Watch for a moody, chilly, character-driven horror story.
The Innkeepers
Director Ti West’s 2009 breakthrough, “The House of the Devil,” established his throwback aesthetic: suspense over gore, with a particular affection for the genre classics of the late ’70s and early ’80s.
The Woman in Black
This 2012 adaptation of the novel by Susan Hill was a production of the then-recently reanimated Hammer Films, the British studio best remembered for its stylish, engaging and increasingly grisly Gothic horror stories.
Cloverfield
The concept of the “found footage” horror movie — a story told entirely in documentary-style video, shot by the participants, and discovered after the events it captures — was still a fairly fresh one in 2008, when director Matt Reeves fused it with the “Godzilla”-style monster movie to create this inspired “document” of a terrifying alien attack on New York City.
The Bay
The popularity of the style and its (seeming) ease of execution resulted in a glut of “found footage” films in the years following “Cloverfield” — so much so that it took a filmmaker completely removed from genre movies to make it fresh again.
Demon
Watch for a smartly shot creep-out that doubles as a subtle comedy of manners.
Green Room
Watch for a white-knuckle thriller with a serrated edge, like “Die Hard” for the mosh pit set.
The Girl With All the Gifts
This adaptation of the 2014 sci-fi novel by M.R. Carey dwells in the realm of British post-apocalyptic zombie horror familiar to fans of “28 Days Later” and “28 Weeks Later,” but uses its genre trappings as a vehicle for a thoughtful character study and knotty morality play.

Clockwise from top left: “Eyes Without a Face,” “Symbiopsychotaxiplasm: Take One” and “Chungking Express.”Lux Film; Janus Films; Miramax Films
